Article Title: Matter of minutes: Frenzied mob loots Karachi's 'Dream Bazaar' in Pakistan; video goes viral
Article Text: The grand opening of a major clothing store in Karachi , Pakistan, descended into chaos when a large crowd stormed the building, leading to widespread looting and vandalism , according to local media reports.Social media is buzzing with videos showing hundreds of people breaking into the store as staff members inside watched the mob destroy the property.The store, called ' Dream Bazaar ,' had announced special discounts for its opening day, coupled with a social media campaign to attract the public. However, the event quickly spiraled out of control when the management attempted to close the store. The incident occurred in Karachi’s Gulistan-e-Johar, with the store opening at 3 pm and getting emptied within 30 minutes, according to ARY news.Social media videos revealed extensive damage to the building, with clothes scattered on the floor amid broken glass. Some individuals were even seen recording themselves while looting the store. However, TOI couldn't independently verify the authenticity video.According to ARY news, the mall was established by a Pakistani-origin businessman living abroad. Despite the chaos, local police were reportedly absent, though they later stated that they had not been informed about the event beforehand and took control of the situation once they were alerted.Two management representatives were seen in the videos expressing their disappointment at the crowd's behavior, recounting their ordeal. "This mall was opened for the benefit of the people of Karachi, and look at what has happened. People need to change. We rarely see significant investments here, and when they do happen, this is the outcome," one staff member lamented.
Article Summary: The store, called'Dream Bazaar,' had announced special discounts for its opening day, coupled with a social media campaign to attract the public. The event quickly spiraled out of control when the management attempted to close the store. Local police were reportedly absent, though they later stated that they had not been informed about the event beforehand.

Article Title: Utsav Mondal: Utsav Mandal, Hindu youngster attacked by mob inside police station, is alive: Bangladesh army
Article Text:
Dhaka Tribune

RTV News

What exactly happened?

Attacks on Hindus in Bangladesh

With inputs from agencies

On Wednesday, a young Hindu man named Utsav Mondal was attacked by an angry mob inside a police station after allegedly making a comment about the Prophet.While several social media users claimed that Mondal had been beaten to death, a report in theconfirmed that he was alive and undergoing treatment. Another report bystated that the young man was being treated under the supervision of the Bangladesh Army and was no longer in critical condition.A press release issued by the Directorate of Inter-Services Public Relations on Thursday stated that Utsav, 22, had posted derogatory comments about a religious figure. On Wednesday, 4th September, he was apprehended by locals and taken to the office of the Deputy Police Commissioner of Khulna (South) to face legal action. As news spread, a crowd of 3,000 to 3,500 people gathered, demanding public punishment. The situation quickly escalated, prompting the deployment of armed forces to manage the unrest.Despite the presence of military personnel, some members of the crowd forced their way into the Deputy Commissioner’s office and attacked Utsav. Thanks to the intervention of the armed forces, he was rescued alive and is now receiving medical treatment under military supervision.The press release also stated that a case has been filed against Utsav for violating religious sentiments, and once he recovers, he will be handed over to the authorities for legal proceedings. It emphasised that the Bangladesh Army is committed to preventing extrajudicial killings and upholding the rule of law. The public was urged not to be misled by rumours circulating on social media regarding Utsav’s death.The incident took place late on Wednesday night, around 11:45 pm, when false announcements were made via mosque loudspeakers claiming Utsav Mondal had died.According to local reports, Utsav had posted offensive comments about a religious figure on social media. By around 8 pm, several students had tracked him down and taken him to the office of Deputy Police Commissioner (South), Mohammad Tazul Islam, in Sonadanga. As word of his detention spread, a large crowd gathered outside, demanding that Utsav be handed over to them.The situation intensified as the angry mob, calling for immediate justice, surrounded the building. The army and navy were deployed to contain the growing unrest. However, despite their presence, the mob managed to break into the office and brutally attack Utsav.Deputy Police Commissioner Tazul later explained that authorities had assured the crowd that legal actions would be taken, including the filing of a case and due legal process. However, the mob ignored these assurances, assaulting the student and leaving him critically injured.In an attempt to disperse the crowd and restore order, police used mosque loudspeakers to falsely announce Utsav’s death.Earlier, Muhammad Yunus, head of Bangladesh's interim government, firmly dismissed claims that Bangladesh would devolve into another Afghanistan without Sheikh Hasina 's leadership. He urged India to abandon this narrative, calling for a focus on improving bilateral ties instead.Yunus argued that the attacks on minority Hindus in Bangladesh were "more political than communal”. He told PTI in an interview, "These attacks are political in nature and not communal. And India is propagating these incidents in a big way. We have not said that we can't do anything; we have said that we are doing everything."The incidents involved vandalism of Hindu-owned businesses and temples, which took place during student-led violence after Hasina fled the country on August 5. Yunus, appointed as Chief Adviser after Hasina's ouster, reiterated that the issue of minority attacks was "exaggerated" and linked to political unrest, not communal strife.He urged India to shift its perspective on Bangladesh's leadership, stating, "The way forward is for India to come out of the narrative. The narrative is that everybody is Islamist, BNP is Islamist, and everyone else is Islamist and will make this country into Afghanistan. And Bangladesh is in safe hands with Sheikh Hasina at the helm only. India is captivated by this narrative. India needs to come out of this narrative. Bangladesh, like any other nation, is just another neighbour."In his Independence Day address, Prime Minister Narendra Modi expressed optimism that the situation in violence-stricken Bangladesh would stabilize soon. He emphasized that the safety of Hindus and other minorities in the neighbouring country is a matter of concern for 1.4 billion Indians
Article Summary: A young Hindu man named Utsav Mondal was attacked by an angry mob inside a police station after allegedly making a comment about the Prophet. Despite the presence of military personnel, some members of the crowd forced their way into the Deputy Commissioner’s office. Thanks to the intervention of the armed forces, he was rescued alive and is now receiving medical treatment.
